bibl.title: Letter from H.M. Scheiffelin to W.H. Seward
Notes from Liberian Legation In U.S. to Department of State, 1862-1898 T807

div1.p: Legation of Liberia, Yonkers, N.Y. Jany 11th, 1867

Sir It having been ascertained that there is no suitable sailing vessel in the United States Navy, nor any suitable steam vessel that can (in the judgement of the Secy of the Navy) be shared for the purpose of being transferred to the governmen t of Liberia, according to the late act of Congress, their liberal act towards Liberia cannot be made available; of this fact the Liberian gov ernment was not yet, at last dates, apprised; while, in addition to former reasons for desiring it, another still more imminent has arisen.
The government has information that the several tribes along the sea board
To the Hon. William H. Seward Secretary of State Washington D.C.

being dissatisfied with the interference of "Port of Entry" laws with trade with foreign vessels on the coast, have concert plans for attacking and carrying by force of arms, and starvation, Sinoe and Bassa counties, (about two thirds of all the Li -berian coast) and the government of Liberia, not yet aware of the disppoint -ment, which next mail, probably are this, has brought them, instructs me, that it is urgently necessary, that the gun Boat should be there as early as possible; and to put forth all my endeavors that no time may be lost.
Under these circumstances may I ask if the United State government will extendf to Liberia the assistance of one of her Cruizers on that coast.
I have the honor to be with the highest consideration Sir your most obedient servant H.M. Scheiffelin
